newsitem.title: USA: Brent crude offerings in U.S. remain scarce.
newsitem.headline: Brent crude offerings in U.S. remain scarce.

text.p: Foreign crude offerings to the U.S. were fundamentally unchanged Thursday, with North Sea Brent offerings scarce and only a few trades discussed.
Foreign crude players said an early June Vasconia cargo was sold around June West Texas Intermediate/Cushing minus $3.60, after being on offer at minus $3.55.
North Sea arbitrage numbers were slightly wider Thursday, with Brent-WTI around plus $1.60 in favor of WTI, and July at the same level, around five cents higher than Wednesday.
Narrow Brent-Dubai spreads have pushed many North Sea and West African barrels away from the U.S. to destinations in the Far East, traders said.
"The North Sea market has firmed up, but there has been no change in the lack of barrels headed to the Gulf," said a U.S. player.
There was still some discussion of Brent being shown for early June delivery at June WTI -70 cents, steady from Wednesday talk.
Nigerian Brass River remained on offer for early June with asking prices of Dated Brent +$2.05.
Traders noted there was plenty of North Sea Oseberg sweet crude backed-up in the Bahamas.
"There were nominations for two million barrels, but there is no sign of it moving out of there," said a trader.
